{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3466783,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-02T16:58:57.531Z","cooked":"

Posted 20250102 on 2025 Kickoff Release of WPILib — WPILib

We are pleased to announce the availability of the 2025 kickoff release (2025.1.1) of WPILib, the official FIRST libraries for robot programming in Java, C++, and Python.

Changes for 2025

There have been many additions and new features added by the WPILib development team over the past year. We encourage all teams to read the New for 2025 page in the documentation for all the details! Some statistics (just for the main WPILib repository): 739 commits were made since 2024.3.2 by 36 contributors, touching nearly 3,900 files, with 457,830 added and 71,575 removed lines.

Notably, two new tools have been added to the WPILib installer. A new driver-focused dashboard, Elastic, was contributed by Nadav of FRC Team 353. Elliot Scher, a current WPI student, developed an AprilTag field layout calibration tool (WPIcal) inspired by FRC Team 1538’s cowlibration tool. A new Vendor Dependency Manager in VS Code will help teams discover and install vendordeps. On the library front, Java annotation based logging has been added (Epilogue), and the Java units library has been refactored. The units library is a breaking change, but the new API is less complicated to use and more extensible.

Looking Forward to 2027

For the 2026 release, we anticipate that the majority of features will remain consistent with 2025. The WPILib team is excited for the 2027 Mobile Robot Controller and our focus is shifting towards the 2027 release so that teams will be able to take advantage of all the capabilities of the new controller.

Installation Instructions

  • WPILib installation guide
  • GitHub download page

Note: Minimum system requirements: WPILib requires 64-bit Windows 10 or 11 (Arm and 32-bit not supported), Ubuntu 22.04 or 24.04, or macOS 13.3 or higher. C++ teams should note that the latest version of Visual Studio 2022 is required for desktop builds. Mac users will need to have the Xcode Command Line Tools installed before running the installer. This can be done by running xcode-select --install in the Terminal.

Thanks and an Ask

WPILib is run by a small team of volunteers and the community. Many of the features and tools included in WPILib started as community projects or ideas. As the new season begins, we challenge you when writing the next exciting project or feature to think about how you can best share your work with the community! Some projects would be great additions to WPILib and we would love the chance to include them. This is also true of any issues you run into using the current library, we are always looking to make things better for teams! We encourage you to talk to us and discuss what you are doing and how it could fit into future plans. You can reach us on GitHub, Discord, and Chief Delphi.

WPILib’s core members are as follows.

  • Amanda Bessette @ arbessette
  • Ryan Blue @ Ryan_Blue
  • Jonah Bonner @ jwbonner
  • Sam Carlberg @ SamCarlberg
  • Jason Daming @ jdaming
  • Thad House @ Thad_House
  • Peter Johnson @ Peter_Johnson
  • Brad Miller @ BradAMiller
  • Joe Pokorny @ jpokornyiii
  • Joe Ross @ Joe_Ross
  • Elliot Scher
  • Austin Shalit @ AustinShalit
  • Yotam Shlomi @ starlight220
  • Dustin Spicuzza @ virtuald
  • Tyler Veness @ calcmogul
  • David Vo @ auscompgeek
  • Vasista Vovveti @ vyo
  • Zhiquan Yeo @ zeequeue

We would also like to call out the translation coordinators for the documentation. These people help make WPILib accessible to teams all around the world.

  • Ofek Ashery (Hebrew)
  • Regis Bekale (French)
  • Hasan Bilgin (Turkish)
  • Luca Carvalho (Portuguese)
  • Miguel Angel de León Adame (Spanish)
  • Jacob Lubecki (Japanese)
  • Bruno Toso (Portuguese)
  • Atlus Zhang (Chinese)
  • Min Zhang (Chinese)

Major past contributors to WPILib include Eli Barnett, Jaci Brunning, Evan Gilgenbach, Alex Henning, Jonathan Leitschuh, James Kuszmaul, Toby Macaluso, Prateek Machiraju, Paul Malmsten, Peter Mitrano, Kevin O’Brien, Grant Perkins, Patrick Plenefisch, Fred Silberberg, Dalton Smith, and Griffin Tabor.

In addition to these volunteers, many members of the community contribute code, open issues, give ideas, and provide feedback. A huge thanks to these members of the community for their amazing contributions to the library and to the many beta testers this fall.

Has this always been the case?

Screenshot_20250102-1204451181×290 41.4 KB

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2025-01-02T19:05:28.290Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":524,"readers_count":523,"score":159.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":477948,"topic_slug":"wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib","display_username":"Asher Olgeirson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51179,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib/477948/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3466901,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-02T19:17:24.590Z","cooked":"

The recommendation is new; C++ compilation has always been memory intensive, but we’ve had reports that it’s more so this year, particularly on Windows (see this thread: WPILib 2025 Beta Shuffleboard and C++ Build Problems). It has a relationship to the number of cores/threads. Typically Gradle builds fully in parallel based on the number of cores/HTs, which can get quite memory intensive depending on how your project is structured.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2025-01-02T19:18:39.214Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":506,"readers_count":505,"score":176.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":477948,"topic_slug":"wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/wpilib-2025-beta-shuffleboard-and-c-build-problems/477451","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"WPILib 2025 Beta Shuffleboard and C++ Build Problems","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51179,"username":"Cynosure","name":"Asher Olgeirson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cynosure/{size}/184875_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib/477948/8","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"cry","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3466910,"name":"","username":"crueter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-02T19:27:24.785Z","cooked":"

The recommendation of 32GB flat doesn’t seem proper. It should be 2GB per thread, an 8 thread/4 core machine should have no issues with 16GB.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2025-01-02T19:27:24.785Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":474,"readers_count":473,"score":99.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":477948,"topic_slug":"wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13575,"username":"Peter_Johnson","name":"Peter Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50684,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6032 | QDash"},"post_url":"/t/wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib/477948/10","custom_user_title":"6032 | QDash","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3466914,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-02T19:31:32.632Z","cooked":"

Yes, it’s not flat, but 16 GB isn’t really enough for 4C8T, because there are other things running (OS, web browser, dashboard, vscode, intellisense engine, Gradle…). The rule of thumb I’ve typically used is 4-8 GB for that base use plus 2 GB/thread (for the compilers). We could put in the more complicated formula, but wanted a number that stuck out more to people because there are far too many laptops out there now with 4C8T or more and only 16 GB of RAM.

It’s probably also worth documenting how to set --max-workers in Gradle if you have a machine with too little RAM for its core count. It’s going to mean a slower build, but at least it won’t crash your machine that way.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2025-01-02T19:34:38.961Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":471,"readers_count":470,"score":164.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":477948,"topic_slug":"wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50684,"username":"crueter","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/crueter/{size}/258043_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib/477948/11","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3466936,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-02T19:53:56.953Z","cooked":"
SamCarlberg:

LED animation API

A good replacement for expensive and unreliable LED drivers whose failures nearly cost us going to World’s.

Oblarg:

annotation-based logging

I like modern tools and look forward to checking out this logging option. There is a bit of dread, though, of yet another logging tool that I have to learn, evaluate and teach the students. Sorry - much easier to get excited about shiny flashing lights!

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2025-01-02T19:53:56.953Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":451,"readers_count":450,"score":120.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":477948,"topic_slug":"wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib/477948/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3466938,"name":"alst","username":"alst","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/alst/{size}/11646_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-02T20:01:30.809Z","cooked":"
Peter_Johnson:

It’s probably also worth documenting how to set --max-workers in Gradle if you have a machine with too little RAM for its core count. It’s going to mean a slower build, but at least it won’t crash your machine that way.

Another thing I’ve done in past years is disable the debug build (or release build, whichever one I’m not using). Not sure if this is still relevant in the default 2025 configuration.

Was the root cause of WPILib’s excessive memory usage ever discovered? Or was it CTRE’s gigaheaders?

Using up that much memory is still rather unusual; in fact I’ve even managed to compile QtWebEngine with -j8 (4C8T) and only 8GB free, while a -j17 build (8C16T) rarely, if ever, eats up 16GB. Nothing else I’ve compiled has come close to this much usage either.

What in particular changed about them in 2025 that makes them this much more resource intensive? Such a seemingly dramatic difference doesn’t seem right to me.

I also hope they have #pragma once or #ifndef HEADERNAME_H etc, otherwise they’re getting continuously recompiled.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2025-01-02T20:22:22.022Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":418,"readers_count":417,"score":88.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":477948,"topic_slug":"wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16147,"username":"Thad_House","name":"Thad House","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/a4c791/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50684,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6032 | QDash"},"post_url":"/t/wpilib-blog-2025-kickoff-release-of-wpilib/477948/17","custom_user_title":"6032 | QDash","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3466978,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-02T20:28:17.056Z","cooked":"

Yes, we have header guards on everything. The problem on Windows seems to be that the MSVC frontend is very slow and memory-intensive. Linux can build twice as fast with less memory on the same hardware. We may spend some time over the next year looking to see if switching to clang-cl is viable; some early testing looks very promising.

The main thing that changed for 2025 was making more of wpimath constexpr-friendly, which moved a number of implementations from source files into headers. And yes, CTRE headers seem to be a contributor as well. But in general, team code is getting ever more complex and math heavy.

I think something else is that a lot of newer Intel systems with their big little had a pretty large increase in core count. The efficiency cores get their own worker too. So the number of cores in each system has gone up too.
